definition: A region (or regions) that include all of the sequence elements necessary to encode a functional transcript. A gene may include regulatory regions, transcribed regions, and/or other functional sequence regions.
A gene that produces at least one transcript that is translated into a protein.
A gene component region which acts as a recombinational unit of a gene whose functional form is generated through somatic recombination.
A region of the genome associated with transcript and/or prediction evidence but where feature classification is imprecise.

A biological region characterized as a single heritable trait in a phenotype screen. The heritable phenotype may be mapped to a chromosome but generally has not been characterized to a specific gene locus.
MGI markers that are not classified as gene including pseudogenes, QTL, transgenes, gene clusters, cytogenetic markers, & unclassified genome features.

A quantitative trait locus (QTL) is a polymorphic locus which contains alleles that differentially affect the expression of a continuously distributed phenotypic trait. Usually it is a marker described by statistical association to quantitative variation in the particular phenotypic trait that is thought to be controlled by the cumulative action of alleles at multiple loci.
A gene that has been transferred naturally or by any of a number of genetic engineering techniques from one organism to another.
A gene that produces an RNA transcript that functions as the gene product.
A gene that encodes a non-coding RNA over 200 nucleotides in length.
A gene that encodes a non-coding RNA transcribed from the opposite DNA strand compared with other transcripts and overlap in part with sense RNA.
A gene that encodes large intervening non-coding RNA.
A gene that encodes a sense intronic long non-coding RNA.
A gene that encodes a sense overlap long non-coding RNA.
A non-coding locus that originates from within the promoter region of a protein-coding gene, with transcription proceeding in the opposite direction on the other strand.
A gene that encodes ribosomal RNA.
A gene that encodes Transfer RNA.
A gene that encodes a Small Nuclear RNA.
A gene that encodes for Small Nucleolar RNA.
A gene that encodes for microRNA.
A gene that encodes for Small Cytoplasmic RNA.
A gene that encodes the signal recognition particle RNA.
A gene that encodes RNase P RNA, the RNA component of Ribonuclease P (RNase P).
A gene that encodes RNase MRP RNA.
A non-coding RNA gene, the RNA product of which is a component of telomerase.
A non-coding RNA gene not classified with established ncRNA functional subcategories.
A gene that encodes an RNA with catalytic activity.
A group of linked markers characterized by related sequence and/or function where the precise location or identity of the individual components is obscure.
A structure within a chromosome or a chromosomal rearrangement that is visible by microscopic examination.
An incomplete chromosome.
The sequence of one or more nucleotides added between two adjacent nucleotides in the sequence.
An interchromosomal mutation where a region of the chromosome is inverted with respect to wild type.
A non reciprocal translocation whereby the participating chromosomes break at their centromeres and the long arms fuse to form a single chromosome with a single centromere.
A chromosomal translocation with two breaks; two chromosome segments have simply been exchanged.
An interchromosomal mutation. Rearrangements that alter the pairing of telomeres are classified as translocations.
An extra chromosome.

A chromosome structure variant whereby a region of a chromosome has been transferred to another position. Among interchromosomal rearrangements, the term transposition is reserved for that class in which the telomeres of the chromosomes involved are coupled (that is to say, form the two ends of a single DNA molecule) as in wild-type.
A cytogenetic marker not classifiable within current cytogenetic subcategories.
A region of sequence from the end of a BAC or YAC clone used as a reagent in mapping and genome assembly.
A region of sequence from the end of a BAC clone that may provide a highly specific marker.
A region of sequence from the end of a YAC clone that may provide a highly specific marker.
A region of sequence from the end of a PAC clone that may provide a highly specific marker.
A region of the genome associated with biological interest (includes regulatory regions, conserved regions and related sequences, repetitive sequences, and viral integrations).
A transposable element that is incorporated into a chromosome by a mechanism that requires reverse transcriptase.
A specific structure at the end of a linear chromosome, required for the integrity and maintenance of the end.
A repeat region containing tandemly repeated sequences having a unit length of 10 to 40 bp.
A genome feature that cannot be classified in any currently recognized genome category.
A region derived from viral infection of germ cells that has been stably integrated into the host genome and is passed on from generation to generation.
A genomic region, containing multiple genes/genome features, within which a mutation event resulted in complex genomic changes affecting multiple features (e.g. not a simple regional deletion).
Regions of a few hundred to a few thousand bases in vertebrate genomes that are relatively GC and CpG rich; they are typically unmethylated and often found near the 5' ends of genes.
A regulatory region composed of the TSS(s) and binding sites for TF complexes of the basal transcription machinery.
Transcription factor binding regions that flank the promotor.
The region of a gene from the 5' most TSS (transcription start site) to the 3' TSS.
A cis-acting sequence that increases the utilization of (some) eukaryotic promoters, and can function in either orientation and in any location (upstream or downstream) relative to the promoter.
A transcription factor binding site with consensus sequence CCGCGNGGNGGCAG, bound by CCCTF-binding factor.
A DNA site where a transcription factor binds.
Regions of spaced out histones, making them accessible to protein interactions.

A region of the genome associated with experimental interest, often used as a reagent for genetic mapping. Includes RFLP and other hybridization probes, sequence-tagged sites (STS), and regions defined by PCR primer pairs such as microsatellite markers).
A non-functional descendant of a functional entity.

A sequence that closely resembles a known functional gene, at another locus within the genome, that is non-functional a consequence of (usually several) mutations that prevent either its transcription or translation (or both).  In general, pseudogenes result from either reverse transcription of a transcript of their normal paralog, in which case the pseudogene typically lacks introns and includes a poly(A) tail, or from recombination, in which case the pseudogene is typically a tandem duplication of its normal paralog.
A recombinational unit of a gene which when incorporated by somatic recombination in the final gene transcript results in a nonfunctional product.
Pseudogene owing to a SNP/DIP but in other individuals/haplotypes/strains the gene is translated.

A regulatory region that controls epigenetic imprinting and affects the expression of target genes in an allele- or parent-of-origin-specific manner. Associated regulatory elements may include differentially methylated regions and non-coding RNAs.
A regulatory region that is part of an intron.
A regulatory region which upon binding of transcription factors, suppress the transcription of the gene or genes they control.
A DNA region that includes DNAse hypersensitive sites located near a gene that confers the high-level, position-independent, and copy number-dependent expression to that gene.

A regulatory region that 1) when located between a CRM and a gene's promoter prevents the CRM from modulating that genes expression and 2) acts as a chromatin boundary element or barrier that can block the encroachment of condensed chromatin from an adjacent region.
A regulatory element that acts in response to a stimulus, usually via transcription factor binding.

A region of nucleic acid from which replication initiates; includes sequences that are recognized by replication proteins, the site from which the first separation of complementary strands occurs, and specific replication start sites.
A regulatory_region that modulates the transcription of a gene or genes.
A region defined by a cluster of experimentally determined transcription starting sites.
